title: According to Kant, what is a purely morally good action, and what is an example? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kant is known for being quite a stickler when it comes to morality. This answer should show you why. For Kant, to be moral is to do your duty, because it is your duty. In his view, doing the right thing for any other reason is not morally praiseworthy. At first, this can seem quite plausible: Imagine two people, Alex and Babette, confronted with a moral choice for which the right answer is not controversial: an old woman has tripped and needs help getting up.Alex helps the old woman to her feet. However, he was with a date at the time, and he only helped the woman because he wanted to look good in his date’s eyes. Normally, he would’ve walked past the woman, as it’s “not his problem”. His actions are not morally praiseworthy because they don’t come from duty.Babette helps the woman to her feet. She did it because it was the right thing to do. Her actions are morally praiseworthy because they come from duty.Surely we want people to be more like Babette than Alex. But wait a second: Babette admits that she enjoys enjoys doing the right thing, and that she felt concern for the woman. She says that her enjoyment of being good and her sense of concern were also strong motivations for her behavior.In a strict Kantian view, she’s now less morally praiseworthy, because she didn’t act from duty alone.Hence Kant is rather strict. What’s good is that a person who obeyed his rule would always do the right thing. What’s bad is that they would be inhuman. I would propose a compromise rule: An action is morally praiseworthy if duty alone was a sufficient motivation. This way, we retain the strong sense of duty without penalizing people for being human. Furthermore, it seems plausible that the best people would be people who do enjoy doing good, since doing their duties would probably involve less willpower.

For Kant, the moral value of an action rests not in the action itself, but in its motivating principal. Hence there can be no purely moral action: no action that, regarded in and of itself, independent of its motivating principle, is actually moral. Moral actions, for Kant, must be done for the sake of being moral. If you “do the right thing” out of fear of consequences, or even because it “just feels right,” then you are acting in conformity with moral virtue, but not virtuously. And moreover it is impossible to judge whether an action is done for the sake of morality as such. Human freedom does not reveal itself unambiguously in the phenomenal realm.

According to Kant, what is a purely morally good action, and what is an example? Follow only maxims which you will to see as a universal rule. That's Kant's line on universalizing maxims. Kant believes an action was morally repugnant if, when everyone did it, it caused social dysfunction. A morally good action according Kant would be telling the truth.
Following his version of the Golden Rule. If its universalizable. Presumably it doesn’t violate human dignity or harm anyone in the means.

Kant did have a somewhat ideosyncratic idea of morality although it appeals to some. Kant would have nothing to do with utilitarianism which suggests a purpose for morality outside ‘morality’ itself. This is the basis for the categorical imperative.
